description: From Old English formest, fyrmest (‚Äúearliest, first, most prominent‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *frumistaz, from the locative stem *fur-, *fr- + the superlative suffix *-umistaz, stem ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *pr-. The suffix *-umistaz was a compound suffix, created from the rarer comparative suffix *-um√¥ (as in Old English fruma) + the regular superlative suffix *-istaz (English -est); *-um√¥ in turn is from Proto-Indo-European *-mHo-.

Cognate with Old Frisian formest, Gothic êçÜêçÇêåøêåºêåπêçÉêçÑêçÉ (frumists). See for, first and Old English fruma for more. Partially cognate to primus, from Proto-Indo-European *pr- + Latin superlative suffix -imus, from Proto-Indo-European *-mHo-.

A comparative former was back-formed analogically, leaving the m from *-um√¥ in place. Later the Old English suffix complex -(u)m-est was conflated with the word most through folk etymology, so that the word is now interpreted as fore +‚Äé -most.

entries.meaning: Positioned in front of (all) others in space, most forward.
examples: Antonyms: back, backmost, hindmost, rear, rearmost

entries.meaning: Of the highest rank or position; of the greatest importance; of the highest priority.
examples: Synonyms: greatest, leading, paramount, primary, principal, top
The exhibition features works by the country‚Äôs foremost artists.
Foremost among the workers‚Äô grievances was the company‚Äôs failure to address the many safety issues in the plant.

No Man hath more nicely observed our Climate, than the Bookseller who bought the Copy of this Work; He knows to a Tittle what Subjects will best go off in a dry Year, and which it is proper to expose foremost, when the Weather-glass is fallen to much Rain.
Alwayes the worst goes foremost, so twill prove I hope
